title: Customising the models to compare
text: might wish show different models.

title: Getting started
text: data prepared metaUI, can read directly import_data(). preprocessing needs done (e.g., labels), can also read file, preprocess pass import_data(). TK - Fisher’s z example equivalent SMD?
code: df <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "barroso2021.csv", package = "metaUI"))  df <- df %>% mutate(   study_label = paste0(author, " (", pub_year, ")", ": ", study_id),   se = sqrt(vi), p.value = 2 * pnorm(-abs(yi)),   continent = factor(continent) %>%      forcats::fct_recode("North America" = "1", "South America" = "2", "Europe" = "3",                         "Asia" = "4", "Africa" = "5", "Oceania" = "6", "NA" = "-999"),   teachers = factor(teachers) %>%      forcats::fct_recode(yes = "1", no = "2") )  df <- import_data(df,   study_label = "study_label", es_field = "yi", se = "se", pvalue = "p.value",   sample_size = "ni",   variance = "vi",    filters = c("Publication year" = "pub_year", Continent = "continent", "Teacher sample" = "teachers"),    es_type = "SMD" )

title: Getting started
code: generate_shiny(df, "Barroso et al 2021 - Maths Anxiety", "Fisher's Z scores")

title: Authors and Citation
text: package maintainer. Maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Ww (2023). metaUI: Package (Title Case). R package version 0.1.0, https://lukaswallrich.github.io/metaUI/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {metaUI: What the Package Does (Title Case)},   author = {Who wrote it},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://lukaswallrich.github.io/metaUI/}, }

title: What the Package Does (Title Case)
text: Meta-analyses based rich datasets can analyzed numerous ways, unlikely authors readers always agree “best ways” analyze data. Whether comes choice model (e.g., random versus fixed effects), methods assessing adjusting publication bias (e.g., z-curve, p-curve, robust Bayesian meta-analysis), moderators included meta-regression, disagreements likely arise. can lead inclusion lengthy robustness checks alternative analyses time-consuming difficult digest. metaUI, R package supports researchers creating interactive Shiny web apps can help - apps allow readers (reviewers) explore meta-analytic datasets variety different ways. Apart allowing readers (reviewers) assess robustness trustworthiness results comprehensively, metaUI allows others assess results relevant , filtering dataset focus specific group participants, region, outcome variable, research method. opportunity users download dataset used upload alternatives, also facilitate updating meta-analyses. idea came researchers created similar web apps meta-analyses well received, yet require substantial time investment advanced coding skills use. metaUI, researchers can get working app simply uploading dataset tagging key variables – still flexibility tailor display line interests requirements.

what: Create the about text for the app — create_about
title: Create the about text for the app — create_about
text: Create text app

title: Create the about text for the app — create_about
code: create_about(   dataset_name,   date = format(Sys.Date(), "%d %b %Y"),   citation = "",   osf_link = "",   contact = "",   ... )

title: Create the about text for the app — create_about
text: dataset_name Name dataset date Date last update. Defaults current date. citation Citation requested author. Defaults empty string. osf_link Link OSF (similar) project data materials available. Defaults empty string. contact Contact information, typically email. Defaults empty string.

what: Format confidence interval based on the bounds — fmt_ci
title: Format confidence interval based on the bounds — fmt_ci
text: Constructs confidence intervals upper lower bounds, placing square brackets

title: Format confidence interval based on the bounds — fmt_ci
code: fmt_ci(lower, upper, digits = 2)

title: Format confidence interval based on the bounds — fmt_ci
text: lower Lower bound(s) confidence interval(s). Numeric, vector numbers upper Lower bound(s) confidence interval(s). Numeric, vector numbers digits Number significant digits, defaults 2

title: Format confidence interval based on the bounds — fmt_ci
text: Taken timesaveR package, copyright also Lukas Wallrich, 2022

what: Format p-value in line with APA standard (no leading 0) — fmt_p
title: Format p-value in line with APA standard (no leading 0) — fmt_p
text: Formats p-value line APA standard, returning without leading 0 < .001 > .99 extremely small large.

title: Format p-value in line with APA standard (no leading 0) — fmt_p
code: fmt_p(p_value, digits = 3, include_equal = TRUE)

title: Format p-value in line with APA standard (no leading 0) — fmt_p
text: p_value Numeric, vector numbers digits Number significant digits, defaults 3 include_equal precise p-values prefixed =? Useful -text reporting, less tables

text: function generates Shiny app. main function package. app can either launched directly, saved folder. saved, folder contain code data needed run app. app can launched sourcing app.R file folder running launch_app().

code: generate_shiny(   dataset,   dataset_name,   eff_size_type_label = NA,   models = get_model_tibble,   save_to_folder = NA,   launch_app = is.na(save_to_folder),   ... )

title: Generate Shiny app — generate_shiny
text: dataset Dataframe returned import_data() dataset_name Name dataset eff_size_type_label label used describe effect size. NA, effect type code dataset used. models models included app. Can either function call, tibble, path file. want change default models, look vignette /get_model_tibble() documentation. Passing file (e.g. "my_models.R") particularly helpful include helper functions save app. , must assign tibble global variable called models_to_run (.e. using <<-). save_to_folder specified, code data app saved folder. Defaults NA, means nothing saved. folder exists, user asked confirm overwriting - unless script run non-interactive mode, case folder overwritten without asking. launch_app app launched? Defaults TRUE saved (.e. save_to_folder NA), FALSE otherwise. ... Arguments passed create_about date Date last update. Defaults current date. citation Citation requested author. Defaults empty string. osf_link Link OSF (similar) project data materials available. Defaults empty string. contact Contact information, typically email. Defaults empty string.

text: tibble models included app - including details estimate extract relevant information model output.

what: Import data from a file and return a data frame — import_data
title: Import data from a file and return a data frame — import_data
text: may want use metafor::escalc() function metafor package calculate effect sizes variances preparation function.

title: Import data from a file and return a data frame — import_data
code: import_data(   data,   study_label,   es_field,   se,   pvalue,   sample_size,   variance,   filters,   url = NA,   es_type = "SMD",   article_label = NA,   es_label = NA )

title: Import data from a file and return a data frame — import_data
text: data path .csv file read data frame study_label Character. Name field use id/study label es_field Character. Name field use effect size se Character. Name field use standard error effect size. pvalue Character. Name field use p-value effect size. sample_size Character. Name field use sample size variance Character. Name field use sampling variances. filters Character. List fields use filters - can named different labels displayed url Character. Field URLs DOIs link . DOIs can format "10.1234/5678" full links. Defaults NA. es_type Character. Type effect size. Defaults "SMD" (standardized mean difference). Check metafor::escalc() function options. article_label Character. Field article labels. used report number references addition number independent samples. es_label Character. Label individual effect sizes - needed multiple effect sizes per study/sample. Defaults NA. Defaults NA, case, multiple effect sizes simply numbered.

title: Import data from a file and return a data frame — import_data
text: tibble data file/input reformatted metaUI

title: Import data from a file and return a data frame — import_data
code: if (FALSE) { import_data("my_meta.csv", "study_id", "cohens_d", c("Country" = "country", "Year" = "year")) }

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
text: function performs \(p\)-curve analysis using meta object calculated effect size data.

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
code: pcurve(x, effect.estimation = FALSE, N, dmin = 0, dmax = 1)

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
text: x Either object class meta, generated metagen, metacont, metacor, metainc, metabin function, dataframe containing calculated effect size (named TE, log-transformed based ratio), standard error (named seTE) study label (named studlab) study. effect.estimation Logical. true effect size underlying p-curve estimated? set TRUE, vector containing total sample size study must provided N. FALSE default. N numeric vector length number effect sizes included x specifying total sample size \(N\) corresponding effect. needed effect.estimation = TRUE. dmin effect.estimation = TRUE: lower limit effect size (\(d\)) space true effect size searched. Must greater equal 0. Default 0. dmax effect.estimation = TRUE: upper limit effect size (\(d\)) space true effect size searched. Must greater 0. Default 1.

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
text: Returns plot main results pcurve analysis: P-curve plot: plot displaying observed \(p\)-curve significance results right-skewness flatness test. Number studies: number studies provided analysis, number significant \(p\)-values included analysis, number studies \(p<0.025\) used half-curve tests. Test results: results right-skewness flatness test, including \(p_{binomial}\) value, well \(z\) \(p\) value full half-curve test. Power Estimate: power estimate 95\ Evidential value: Two lines displaying evidential value present /absent/inadequate based results (using guidelines Simonsohn et al., 2015, see Details). True effect estimate: effect.estimation set TRUE, estimated true effect \(\hat{d}\) returned additionally. results saved variable, list class pcurve containing following objects returned: pcurveResults: data frame containing results right-skewness flatness test, including \(p_{binomial}\) value, well \(z\) \(p\) value full half-curve test. Power: power estimate 95\ PlotData: data frame data used \(p\)-curve plot. Input: data frame containing provided effect sizes, calculated \(p\)-values individual results included (significant) effect. EvidencePresent, EvidenceAbsent, kInput, kAnalyzed, kp0.25: results \(p\)-curve analysis, including presence/absence evidence interpretation, number provided/significant/\(p<0.025\) studies. I2: \(^2\)-Heterogeneity studies provided input (x class meta). class.meta.object: class original object provided x.

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
text: P-curve Analysis \(P\)-curve analysis (Simonsohn, Simmons & Nelson, 2014, 2015) proposed method detect \(p\)-hacking publication bias meta-analyses. \(P\)-Curve assumes publication bias generated researchers publish non-significant results, also analysts “play” around data ("\(p\)-hacking"; e.g., selectively removing outliers, choosing different outcomes, controlling different variables) non-significant finding becomes significant (.e., \(p<0.05\)). method assumes specific research question, \(p\)-values smaller 0.05 included studies follow right-skewed distribution true effect exists, even power single studies (relatively) low. Conversely, left-skewed \(p\)-value distribution indicates presence \(p\)-hacking absence true underlying effect. control "ambitious" \(p\)-hacking, \(P\)-curve also incorporates "half-curve" test (Simonsohn, Simmons & Nelson, 2014, 2015). Simonsohn et al. (2014) stress \(p\)-curve analysis used test statistics actually interest context included study, detailed table documenting reported results used \(p\)-curve analysis created communicating results (link). Implementation function generate \(p\)-curve conduct analysis, function reuses parts R code underlying P-curve App 4.052 (Simonsohn, 2017). effect sizes included meta object data.frame provided x transformed \(z\)-values internally, used calculate p-values conduct Stouffer Binomial test used \(p\)-curve analysis. Interpretations function concerning presence absence/inadequateness evidential value made according guidelines described Simonsohn, Simmons Nelson (2015): Evidential value present: right-skewness test significant half curve \(p<0.05\) \(p\)-value right-skewness test \(<0.1\) half full curve. Evidential value absent inadequate: flatness test \(p<0.05\) full curve flatness test half curve binomial test \(p<0.1\). effect size estimation, pcurve function implements parts loss function presented Simonsohn, Simmons Nelson (2014b). function generates loss function candidate effect sizes \(\hat{d}\), using \(D\)-values Kolmogorov-Smirnov test metric fit, value \(\hat{d}\) minimizes \(D\) estimated true effect. note lack robustness \(p\)-curve analysis results noted meta-analyses substantial heterogeneity (van Aert, Wicherts, & van Assen, 2016). Following van Aert et al., adjusted effect size estimates reported interpreted analyses \(^2\) values 50 percent. warning message therefore printed pcurve function x class meta -study heterogeneity meta-analysis substantial (.e., \(^2\) greater 50 percent).

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
text: Harrer, M., Cuijpers, P., Furukawa, T., & Ebert, D. D. (2019). Meta-Analysis R: Hands-Guide. DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.2551803. Chapter 9.2. Simonsohn, U., Nelson, L. D., & Simmons, J. P. (2014a). P-curve: Key File-drawer. Journal Experimental Psychology, 143(2), 534. Simonsohn, U., Nelson, L. D. & Simmons, J. P. (2014b). P-Curve Effect Size: Correcting Publication Bias Using Significant Results. Perspectives Psychological Science 9(6), 666–81. Simonsohn, U., Nelson, L. D. & Simmons, J. P. (2015). Better P-Curves: Making P-Curve Analysis Robust Errors, Fraud, Ambitious P-Hacking, Reply Ulrich Miller (2015). Journal Experimental Psychology, 144(6), 1146-1152. Simonsohn, U. (2017). R code P-Curve App 4.052. http://p-curve.com/app4/pcurve_app4.052.r (Accessed 2019-08-16). Van Aert, R. C., Wicherts, J. M., & van Assen, M. . (2016). Conducting meta-analyses based p values: Reservations recommendations applying p-uniform p-curve. Perspectives Psychological Science, 11(5), 713-729.

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
text: Mathias Harrer & David Daniel Ebert

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
code: # Example 1: Use metagen object, do not estimate d suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(meta)) data("ThirdWave") #> Warning: data set ‘ThirdWave’ not found meta1 <- metagen(TE, seTE, studlab = ThirdWave$Author, data = ThirdWave) #> Error in metagen(TE, seTE, studlab = ThirdWave$Author, data = ThirdWave): object 'ThirdWave' not found pcurve(meta1) #> Error in pcurve(meta1): could not find function "pcurve"  # Example 2: Provide Ns, calculate d estimate N <- c(105, 161, 60, 37, 141, 82, 97, 61, 200, 79, 124, 25, 166, 59, 201, 95, 166, 144) pcurve(meta1, effect.estimation = TRUE, N = N) #> Error in pcurve(meta1, effect.estimation = TRUE, N = N): could not find function "pcurve"  # Example 3: Use metacont object, calculate d estimate data("amlodipine") meta2 <- metacont(n.amlo, mean.amlo, sqrt(var.amlo),   n.plac, mean.plac, sqrt(var.plac),   data = amlodipine, studlab = study, sm = "SMD" ) N <- amlodipine$n.amlo + amlodipine$n.plac pcurve(meta2, effect.estimation = TRUE, N = N, dmin = 0, dmax = 1) #> Error in pcurve(meta2, effect.estimation = TRUE, N = N, dmin = 0, dmax = 1): could not find function "pcurve"  # Example 4: Construct x object from scratch sim <- data.frame(   "studlab" = c(paste("Study_", 1:18, sep = "")),   "TE" = c(     0.561, 0.296, 0.648, 0.362, 0.770, 0.214, 0.476,     0.459, 0.343, 0.804, 0.357, 0.476, 0.638, 0.396, 0.497,     0.384, 0.568, 0.415   ),   "seTE" = c(     0.338, 0.297, 0.264, 0.258, 0.279, 0.347, 0.271, 0.319,     0.232, 0.237, 0.385, 0.398, 0.342, 0.351, 0.296, 0.325,     0.322, 0.225   ) ) pcurve(sim) #> Error in pcurve(sim): could not find function "pcurve"

what: Round function that returns trailing zeroes — round_
title: Round function that returns trailing zeroes — round_
text: Particularly creating tables, often desirable keep numbers width. round() similar functions drop trailing zeros - version keeps thus rounds 1.201 1.20 rather 1.2 2 digits requested.

title: Round function that returns trailing zeroes — round_
code: round_(x, digits = 2)

title: Round function that returns trailing zeroes — round_
text: x Numeric vector rounded digits Number significant digits

text: Character vector rounded values, trailing zeroes needed show digits figures decimal point

title: Calculate the standard error from the effect size and p-value — se.from.p
code: se.from.p(effect.size, p, N, effect.size.type = 'difference',     calculate.g = FALSE)

title: Calculate the standard error from the effect size and p-value — se.from.p
text: effect.size Numeric vector single number. effect size, standardized mean difference, Hedges' \(g\) continuous effect size. p Numeric vector single number. exact \(p\)-value corresponding effect size. N Numeric vector single number. total number samples used calculate effect size/\(p\)-value. effect.size.type type effect sizes provided effect.size. effect sizes based differences (e.g., mean differences), parameter set "difference". effect sizes based ratios (e.g., risk ratio, odds ratio), parameter set "ratio". calculate.g Logical. Calculates standardized mean difference corrected small sample bias (Hedges' \(g\)). FALSE default.

title: Calculate the standard error from the effect size and p-value — se.from.p
text: dataframe containing following columns: (log)EffectSize: input effect size. Log-transformed effect.size.type "ratio". Hedges.g: calculated Hedges' g values (calculate.g=TRUE). (log)StandardError: standard error (SE) effect size. Log-transformed effect.size.type "ratio". (log)LLCI (log)ULCI: lower upper 95\ function calculates standard error effect size provided exact \(p\)-value (continuous) effect size according formula Altman Bland (2011). function calculates standard error, standard deviation 95\ interval effect size given effect size exact \(p\)-value. function can used : effect sizes based differences (e.g., mean differences) setting effect.size.type "difference", effect sizes based ratios (e.g. risk ratios, odds ratios hazard ratios) setting effect.size.type "ratio". ratios used, function returns log-transformed effect sizes, standard error, standard deviation confidence interval, can used meta-analytic pooling using metagen function, along original effect size confidence interval. # Example 1: one single effect size se..p(   effect.size = 0.71, p = 0.013, N = 75,   effect.size.type = "difference", calculate.g = TRUE )# Example 2: vector effect sizes (Odds Ratio) effect.size <- c(0.91, 1.01, 0.72, 0.43) p <- c(0.05, 0.031, 0.001, 0.09) N <- c(120, 86, 450, 123) se..p(   effect.size = effect.size, p = p, N = N,   effect.size.type = "ratio" ) Altman D.G. & Bland J.M. (2011) obtain confidence interval p value. BMJ 343:d2090. Mathias Harrer & David Daniel Ebert

what: Convert a tibble/dataframe to tribble code — to_tribble

text: Tribbles easy way legibly input data, therefore helpful teaching interactive work. function takes tibble returns code can recreate . Note function converts "NA" NA converts factors characters retain levels.

code: to_tribble(x, show = FALSE, digits = 5)

text: x tibble/dataframe converted tribble code show Logical. Print code (otherwise, returned - print cat() get linebreaks etc) digits Number digits round numeric columns .
